item.title: Scale React Development with Nx
item.description: I’m happy to announce the release of my latest Egghead course on “Scale React development with Nx”. Let me briefly dive into what the course is about, why I targeted it to React.js developers and who should watch it!

item.title: I'm new to Nx. Where do I get started?
item.description: If you are new to Nx, but curious, here are a couple of pointers and links where and how to get started.

item.title: Access Selenium Test Screenshots on failed GitLab Pipeline Steps
item.description: You know those moments when your Selenium based test succeeds locally, but for some weird reason fails on CI? The only hope: screenshots of the failed run! Let’s quickly have a look at how we can tell GitLab to store those screenshots on a failed run.

item.title: Using the Nx Dependency Graph in Custom Scripts
item.description: One of the powerful pillars of the open-source Nx monorepo toolkit is its dependency graph. In this article, we’re going to look into how we can leverage it in our own scripts.

item.title: Detect when node_modules are out of sync
item.description: I’m pretty sure this already happened to you as well. You pull down the latest main branch or jump to some feature branch and you start getting weird errors. Until only later you recognize you forgot to execute an npm install. Let’s look into how we can avoid that.

item.title: Partial Commits in WebStorm
item.description: I think partial commits should be avoided as they might lead to inconsistent commits if you don’t test them properly. But sometimes they’re handy too. In this article I’m quickly showing how partial commits can be done in Webstorm.

item.title: Debug Jest with VSCode
item.description: Jest has become the goto testing framework in the frontend space, whether it is for React or for Angular. In Nx it is even the default choice when generating a new Angular app. Debugging can be a bit more cumbersome though, in contrast to Karma. Let’s see.

item.title: Create Code Snippets for Visual Studio Code with ease
item.description: When writing software, even when writing a blog post using Markdown, there are some pieces you have to write again and again. Either you’re lazy or you don’t remember the exact syntax, code snippets can really help here. Let’s see how.

item.title: Setup your Workstation for JavaScript Development
item.description: You want to learn about modern web development with JavaScript? Maybe Angular? Well, then it’s time to get you setup properly to get started. In this article we’ll go through some of the tools.

item.title: Blog Like a Hacker with Jekyll and Nitrous.IO
item.description: One of the best moves I probably did about half a year ago was to move my Blog from blogger to Jekyll, hosted on GitHub.

item.title: Perfect Workflow in Sublime Text 2
item.description: I previously wrote about my Sublime Text setup. Well, Tuts+ has published a quite nice Sublime Text tutorial showing most of Sublime’s features. Regardless of whether you’re a Sublime Text enthusiast or not, you should definitely take a look at the tutorial.

item.title: My Sublime Text Setup
item.description: I absolutely love this editor. A ridiculously fast editor which has everything you’d love to have, from a simple notepad to an advanced, extensible IDE with auto-completion and highlighting.

item.title: Test Your App Under Slow Network Speeds
item.description: I guess that I don’t have to start talking about the importance of testing in the software development process. There are couple of different kind of tests which I’m not going to mention now, but generally speaking a good test should verify the correct implementation of the business requirements but also test the software on its boundaries and edge cases.
